5. qua et illusores et contemptores. Added by some edd.: ‘ inasmuch as they are its scoffers and despiserS.'

6. Mimice philosophi, etc. Tertullian manifests here a character- istic tone of unfairness towards Greek philosophers of eminence. The anxiety, aryumenti caussa, to condemn everything non-Christian leads him to point the finger of scorn at the personal failings of the philo· sophers, and prevents him from appreciating the true value of their philosophy. The opposite method of the Alexandrian apologists has been remarked on in the Introduction.

7. corrumpunt. See note, ch. 3.
